props.header: The Michael C. Carlos Museum collects, preserves, exhibits, and interprets art and artifacts from antiquity to the present.
props.text:
Since 1919, the Carlos Museum has been a beacon for people seeking to enrich their lives by studying and experiencing art. It has become one of the premier museums in the Southeast, featuring a renowned collection of artwork from ancient Egypt, Nubia, the Near East, Greece, Rome, the Americas, Africa, and Asia, as well as a collection of works on paper from the Renaissance to the present.

In addition to the collection’s inspiring beauty, pieces provide a window into other worlds, giving visitors a chance to experience different cultures and religions in a way that’s meaningful, educational, and enjoyable while also promoting interdisciplinary teaching and research.

props.text: We need to care about our past in order to prepare for our future.

props.title: In 2036, Curators Are Key
props.body: Curators and conservators are the heart of the Carlos Museum, leading scholarly production, enhancing student engagement, and cementing the museum’s and university’s reputation. Now is the time to renew support and commit to making the Carlos Museum a best-in-class experience. An investment in 2O36 will facilitate the hiring and retention of curators specializing in pieces from Africa, the Americas, Asia, Egypt, Greece and Rome, and Works on Paper. To amplify their work, curators and conservators will also have additional funds for acquisitions, research, professional development, internships, exhibitions, and travel.

props.title: With 2O36, the Permanent Collection Is Permanent
props.body:
The Carlos Museum holds one of the most comprehensive collections in the Southeast, with awe-inspiring artwork from all around. With your help, 2O36 will ensure these treasures have a permanent, dedicated home at Emory. Not only will an endowed gallery continue to build and expand upon the museum’s legacy, it will provide resources to find new ways to attract and engage our diverse audiences.

Imagine the possibilities: pieces from Nubia, Rome, Greece, and more, using an exhibition design that inspires audiences through rich storytelling and dynamic installations. Putting resources in place now will ensure the Carlos Museum grows as a powerful cultural and intellectual hub for students and remains a favorite place for its devoted and wide-reaching audiences.

props.title: New Exhibitions Are Headed for 2036
props.body:
Museums are places to explore and discover; to remember where we’ve been and consider how our past shapes our present and future. While permanent collections go a long way in establishing a museum’s identity, special exhibits are equally fundamental, bringing in exciting new works that increase publicity and invigorate the museum’s mission.

With that in mind, 2O36 will fund a special exhibition gallery to house prestigious pieces from national and international collaborators. Through this unique space, the Carlos Museum will take its reputation to the next level, increasing programming across the board and attracting broad audiences.
props.media_text: 2O36 will fund a special exhibition gallery to house prestigious pieces from national and international collaborators.

items.title: In 2036, Students Come First
items.description: The Carlos Museum is committed to being a space where Emory students feel welcome and encouraged to participate. All Emory students enjoy free admission and membership, in addition to a range of enrichment opportunities, from workshops to internships to formal courses. Still, the museum plans to up the ante. With your support, 2O36 will further expand engagement initiatives, developing programs that invite students to deepen their relationship to the Carlos Museum and discover surprising connections with their classroom studies.

items.title: In 2036, the Past Speaks to the Present
items.description:
The Carlos Museum has always found ways to curate an experience that’s equal parts engaging and educational. Hence, the variety of programming options designed to supplement and complement exhibitions.

2O36 will continue that tradition, launching a new lecture series—Ancients Among Us. This annual interdisciplinary program will bring fresh perspectives from contemporary artists, writers, and thinkers inspired by antiquity, challenging both Emory and public attendees to look anew at our shared human history. As audiences continue to search for surprising and captivating storytelling, the Carlos Museum sees this series as a thrilling new way to fulfill its mission.

items.title: Conserving and Preserving in 2036
items.description: The museum’s Parsons Conservation Lab is the only one of its kind in the region, preserving tens of thousands of priceless objects while providing students the rare chance to gain hands-on experience with examination, analysis, preventive care, and treatment. Suffice to say, its importance to the Carlos Museum’s mission and reputation can’t be overstated. Funding from 2O36 will support essential preservation for a wide variety of materials, as well as continuing research and collaboration initiatives among staff, faculty, and students.

items.title: Funding New Acquisitions in 2036
items.description:
Original works of art are the museum’s raison d'être. Consider the purchase of the Niagara Museum’s Egyptian art collection in 1998: just one example of how purchasing significant works of art is a pivotal part of the museum’s efforts to build community and increase access to the arts.

2O36 will allow the Carlos Museum to acquire exceptional artwork and foster the growth of the collection in exciting and meaningful ways. When you invest in 2O36, you invest in the museum’s ability to inspire our community, elevate our global standing, and reinforce our commitment to promoting the arts at Emory and throughout Atlanta.

items.title: Empowering Teachers in 2036
items.description: As public funding shrinks for school field trips, it’s more important than ever for the Carlos Museum to provide teachers with the tools and funding they need to get students excited about the arts. 2O36 will generate support for innovative, compelling, object-based workshops. By developing tailored teaching resources, the museum will increase its ability to reach younger audiences and make good on its educational mission.

items.title: With 2O36, Technology Tells a Story
items.description: No 21st-century museum can excel without using technology to help tell a story. With your support and generosity, 2O36 will allow the museum to continue to leverage unique technologies while maintaining its laser focus on access and engagement for all, at little to no cost. The museum’s plans include digital exhibition screens, with updated content and audio guides for visitors, and heat and humidity monitors designed to preserve collection pieces. These are just a few of the potential additions that are sure to enhance the audience experience and guarantee the Carlos Museum can continue to be enjoyed for years to come.

items.title: In 2036, Art is For Everyone
items.description: Accessibility is a top priority for the Carlos Museum. By making an intentional effort to remove barriers to entry, 2O36 can provide more opportunities for children, students, and families to experience firsthand all the museum has to offer. Extended hours, free days, camp and workshop scholarships, free admission to university partners, and discounted programs for Title 1 schools are all on the table. The more we can increase access for all, the more we can fulfill the Carlos Museum’s mission.
